relevance.relevance: The study is relevant as it examines the transition from shepherding to fencing in colonial Australia, highlighting the impact of technological change (fencing) on labor displacement (shepherds).

design.sample_characteristics: Shepherds in colonial Australia, including convicts, emancipists, free men, women, children, and non-whites.

dependent_variables.displaced: Shepherds were displaced by the adoption of fencing.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: Shepherds were replaced by fences, leading to changes in employment.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Wages increased slightly over time, but the cost per head of sheep declined.

text_fragments: "Shepherds were a critical component of the early wool industry in colonial Australia and persisted even after fencing was adopted."
"Fences only replaced shepherds when pastoralists realised that the new technology of fences, combined with other changes, would give them higher profits."
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study provides a detailed account of the transition from shepherding to fencing, highlighting the economic and social impacts on shepherds.

historical_context.economic_conditions: Period of growth in the wool industry, with labor shortages during the gold rushes.
historical_context.institutional_context: Labor policies included the Masters and Servants Act, which favored employers.

outcomes.main_findings: Shepherds were gradually replaced by fencing as it became more economically viable for pastoralists.
outcomes.conclusions: The transition to fencing was driven by economic factors, including labor shortages and the realization of higher profits with fenced paddocks.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The displacement of shepherds contributed to the growth of the wool industry and the economic development of colonial Australia.
